Lesson Title: A Star is Born! Stellar Lifecycle Evolution and How Stars Work
Lesson Summary: How are stars created, and what happens to them over the course of their lifecycle?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

 

 

  • Understand that our sun is a star, similar to many other stars in the universe
  • Become familiar with the basic concepts of stellar formation and evolution
  • Develop an awareness of the many different kinds of stars and their defining characteristics

 

EXTENSION TOPICS:

 

  • “Going Out with a Bang! What Happens When a Star Goes Supernova”
Short Description: How are stars created, and what happens to them over the course of their lifecycle?

Lesson Summary: Conversion of direct current (DC) power to alternating current (AC) power; why is this required for interconnection to the energy grid? What are the differences between AC and DC power

Lesson Title: Accounting: Making journal entries for a service business.
Lesson Summary: How do service business process their invoices, and sales to keep an accurate general journal and general ledger?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson students will be able to:

  • process invoices and sales orders
  • enter information into the general journal
  • enter information into the general ledger
Short Description: How do service business process their invoices, and sales to keep an accurate general journal and general ledger?

Lesson Summary: This lesson would explore altered states of consciousness, specifically psychoactive drug use and addiction. Areas of potential instruction include describing how tolerance and addiction work physiologically and psychologically. Examining the common misconceptions about addiction. Identifying and describing the effects of depressants, stimulants and hallucinogens.
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will be able to answer the following questions:

  • How does the misuse of drugs affect daily like?
  • Why is it important to know about different types of psychoactive drugs?
  • What are Biological, Psychological and Social-Cultural influences on drug use and addiction?
Lesson Educational Standards:
APA Consciousness Content Standard 3: Categories of psychoactive drugs and their effects

3.1 Characterize the major categories of psychoactive drugs and their effects.

3.2 Describe how psychoactive drugs act at the synaptic level.

3.3 Evaluate the biological and psychological effects of psychoactive drugs.

3.4 Explain how culture and expectations influence the use and experience of drugs.
Short Description: This lesson would explore altered states of consciousness, specifically psychoactive drug use and addiction. Areas of potential instruction include describing how tolerance and addiction work physiologically and psychologically. Examining the common misconceptions about addiction. Identifying and describing the effects of depressants, stimulants and hallucinogens.

Lesson Summary:
• How do ads work to persuade consumers to buy products or services?
  • What are differences between print, social, and television advertising?
  • Why is it important to understand how ads work and analyze their messaging?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
Learning Objectives:

Students will learn

  • What techniques advertisers use to persuade
  • How ads use a mix of images and text to achieve a purpose
  • How ad writers use the principles of narrative / storytelling
  • Why it is important to consider who is represented in ads, and who isnÕt
  • How advertisers use demographics to target their ads

 

Resources:

  • Persuasive Techniques in Advertiting, Read Write Think (NCTE resource): http://www.readwritethink.org/classroom-resources/lesson-plans/persuasive-techniques-advertising-1166.html?tab=4
  • 11 Activities for Teaching About Advertising, Institute for Humane Education: https://humaneeducation.org/blog/2017/6-activities-for-teaching-about-advertising/


Tips:

  • Explain the challenges of creating ads Ñ what issues/problems come up?
  • Show any in-process materials: storyboards, initial proposals, edits
  • Consider discussing the ethics of advertising
Short Description: How do we create advertisements that persuade consumers to purchase a product or service and what are the optimal mediums for advertising for different kinds of businesses?

Lesson Title: Analyzing water quality data and using findings to create a public policy
Lesson Summary: Students will collect data on a local waterway and then use their data to create a policy to either continue the health of the waterway or clean up the waterway.
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
• Students will preform laboratory tests and analyze data to identify the quality of water
  • Students will understand the importance of making data informed decisions
  • Students will communicate data and policy
  • Students will collaborate in a group
  • Students will take ownership of their individual role

Lesson vision shared in the powerpoint below

  • https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1G_2B9znDtLkiHsa0AkXSGGX5xhqp2TDNti-wtRXBaTs/edit?usp=sharing
Lesson Educational Standards: 9C.1.3.3.1 Explain the political, societal, economic and environmental impact of chemical products and technologies.
Short Description: Students will collect data on a local waterway and then use their data to create a policy to either continue the health of the waterway or clean up the waterway.

Lesson Title: Are We There Yet? How Astronomical Distances Are Measured Across Space
Lesson Summary: Space is big and getting bigger. How are we able to measure the distances to places we can't actually go to?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • Understand some of the techniques scientists use to measure astronomical distances
  • Become familiar with the basic physics behind the various methodologies
  • Have learned a bit about the various natural phenomena used in the methodologies
Short Description: Space is big and getting bigger. How are we able to measure the distances to places we can't actually go to?

Lesson Summary: What are the core elements used in describing, analyzing and interpreting works of Art? What are the key principles used in arranging a work of art?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • be aware of the major elements of art analysis
  • have used what they have learnt about art elements and principles to analyze a specific piece of art
  • have seen how an art industry professional analyzes a piece of art in real time


Potential Activity for use by teacher in preparation for visit of guest instructor:

In advance of the guest instruction, Students will create a set of Artist Trading Cards (white cardstock that measures 2.5 x 3.5 inches or 64 X 89 mm) in which they will choose a medium of their choice to demonstrate their knowledge of each of the seven art elements. Artist Trading Cards (ATCs) are miniature works of art that can be traded between students. Students may choose their own theme and can be made with any media, materials, or techniques. When the guest instructor is present, students will exhibit and verbally present and explain the Artist Trading Cards that they have created. Other potential lessons for this topic could be done to separate each of the art elements into smaller lessons.
Lesson Educational Standards:
Visual Arts/Responding: #VA:Re7.2

  • Anchor Standard: Perceive and analyze artistic work.
  • Enduring Understanding: Visual imagery influences understanding of and responses to the world.
  • Essential Questions: What is an image? Where and how do we encounter images in our world? How do images influence our views of the world?

 

Grade Hs advanced: VA:Re7.2.HSIII:

Determine the commonalities within a group of artists or visual images attributed to a particular type of art, timeframe, or culture


Visual Arts/Creating: #VA:Cr1.1

  • Anchor Standard: Generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.
  • Enduring Understanding: Creativity and innovative thinking are essential life skills that can be developed.
  • Essential Questions: What conditions, attitudes, and behaviors support creativity and innovative thinking? What factors prevent or encourage people to take creative risks? How does collaboration expand the creative process?


Grade Hs advanced: VA:Cr1.1.HSIII:

Visualize and hypothesize to generate plans for ideas and directions for creating art and design that can affect social change.


Visual Arts/Creating: #VA:Cr1.2

  • Anchor Standard: Generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.
  • Enduring Understanding: Artists and designers shape artistic investigations, following or breaking with traditions in pursuit of creative art making goals.
  • Essential Questions: How does knowing the contexts histories, & traditions of art forms help us create works of art & design? Why do artists follow or break from established traditions? How do artists determine what resources are needed to formulate artistic investigations?


Grade Hs advanced: VA:Cr1.2.HSIII:

Choose from a range of materials and methods of traditional and contemporary artistic practices, following or breaking established conventions, to plan the making of multiple works of art and design based on a theme, idea, or concept.


Visual Arts/Connecting: #VA:Cn11.1

  • Anchor Standard: Relate artistic ideas and works with societal, cultural, and historical context to deepen understanding.
  • Enduring Understanding: People develop ideas and understandings of society, culture, and history through their interactions with and analysis of art.
  • Essential Questions: How does art help us understand the lives of people of different times, places, and cultures? How is art used to impact the views of a society? How does art preserve aspects of life?


Grade Hs advanced: VA:Cn11.1.HSIII:

Appraise the impact of an artist or a group of artists on the beliefs, values, and behaviors of a society.
Short Description: Art elements are used as the foundational components within a work of art or design and the art principles are how the art elements are arranged within a work of art/design.

Lesson Summary: What services can a bank provide to me and how do I make use of a bankÕs services?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • understand how to open a bank account and how to deposit and withdraw money
  • understand how to use online banking services safely
  • know what the difference is between a credit and a debit card
  • have visited a bank and understand how to make use of the bank in person
  • know what a credit score is and why it is important
Short Description: What services can a bank provide to me and how do I make use of a bankÕs services?

Lesson Summary: What impact do genetics have upon behavior? Is the impact significant or is environment the overwhelming determinant of behavior?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will

  • be aware of the impact of heredity and environment on behavior of an individual
  • understand how evolved tendencies can influence behavior
  • have seen examples of genetic impacts on behavior
  • have learnt about recent advances in genetic research within the sphere of psychology and behavior
Lesson Educational Standards:
APA Biological Basis of Behavior Content Standard 3: The interaction between biological factors and experience

3.1 Describe concepts in genetic transmission.

3.2 Describe the interactive effects of heredity and environment.

3.3 Explain how evolved tendencies influence behavior.


APA Biological Basis of Behavior Content Standard 4: Methods and issues related to biological advances

4.1 Identify tools used to study the nervous system.

4.2 Describe advances made in neuroscience.

  • 4.3 Discuss issues related to scientific advances in neuroscience and genetics.
Short Description: Describe and analyze the ways genetics can impact behavior.

Lesson Summary: This lesson should help students identify and describe the different biomedical treatments used in treating various psychological disorders.
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • have learnt how biomedical treatments are used in the treatment of psychological disorders
  • be aware of how brain stimulation techniques and psychosurgery in treating specific disorders. understand some of the legal, ethical and professional issues of treating psychological disorders using biomedical treatments
  • have seen how healthy lifestyle choices might be encouraged in conjunction with biomedical treatments for psychological disorders


An extension topic could involve drug research and the use of double-blind studies in evaluating of a drugÕs effectiveness
Lesson Educational Standards:
APA Treatment of Psychological Disorders Content Standard 1: Perspectives on treatment

  • 1.1 Explain how psychological treatments have changed over time and among cultures.
  • 1.2 Match methods of treatment to psychological perspectives.
  • 1.3 Explain why psychologists use a variety of treatment options.


APA Treatment of Psychological Disorders Content Standard 2: Categories of treatment and types of treatment providers

  • 2.1 Identify biomedical treatments.
  • 2.2 Identify psychological treatments.
  • 2.3 Describe appropriate treatments for different age groups.
  • 2.4 Evaluate the efficacy of treatments for particular disorders.
  • 2.5 Identify other factors that improve the efficacy of treatment.
  • 2.6 Identify treatment providers for psychological disorders and the training required for each.


APA Treatment of Psychological Disorders Content Standard 3: Legal, ethical, and professional issues in the treatment of psychological disorders

  • 3.1 Identify ethical challenges involved in delivery of treatment.
  • 3.2 Identify national and local resources available to support individuals with psychological disorders and their families (e.g., NAMI and support groups).
Short Description: Differentiating among psychotherapy, biomedical therapy and an eclectic approach to treatment of disorders.

Lesson Title: Bridge Building Part 1: How do engineers design bridges to carry heavy loads?
Lesson Summary: How do we build bridges that are strong enough to withhold heavy loads traveling over them? What factors do engineers consider and what techniques do they use to ensure that bridges are strong enough to support the necessary loads?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • have an understanding of the approaches, techniques and math used in designing bridges to support specific loads
  • be shown examples of specific bridge designs that have both been successful and unsuccessful and why they were successful or unsuccessful (Would be good for students to see the engineering design principles behind world famous bridges)
  • be aware of the different types of stress placed on bridges and type of structures used to address these types of stress
  • understand the metrics used to measure stress on a bridge structure

 

EXTENSION IF THIS LESSON IS TAUGHT IN CONJUNCTION BRIDGE BUILDING 2:

Students will be presented with the toothpick bridge building challenge attached and be told that Guest instructor will come back in 2-3 weeks to review their toothpick bridges, give feedback on their design and stress test the load bearing capacity of the bridges.

 

Resources:

Youtube video showing stress testing of bridges built by students

Competition instructions
Short Description: How do engineers build bridges which can withstand the heavy loads of vehicles that travel over them?

Lesson Title: Bridge Building Part 2: Testing the load bearing capacity of Bridges
Lesson Summary: How can we measure the weight bearing capacity of bridges to determine which bridges are the strongest?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
NOTE: THIS LESSON IS INTENDED TO BE TAUGHT AS A FOLLOW ON TO THE FOLLOWING LESSON: 

Bridge Building Part 1: How do engineers design bridges to carry heavy loads?nnBefore the start of class students will have constructed a toothpick bridge built out of a maximum of 500 toothpicks.


During the lesson time, the guest instructor should:

  • provide an overview of how engineers test the stress loading capacity of a bridge
  • listen and give feedback to each student team as they present the reasoning behind and process of building their bridge
  • explain how they would use their engineering experience in building a toothpick bridge and determining the strongest design
  • conduct, together with the teacher, load bearing tests on each bridge until they collapse
  • announce the highest load bearing bridge winner AND the most innovative design they saw on their opinion
  • offer concluding thoughts on the nature of engineering challenges they face in their daily work and why they enjoy their career as engineers


Resources:Bridge Building Rules
Short Description: How can we measure the weight  bearing capacity of bridges to determine which bridges are the strongest?

Lesson Title: Bridges: the engineering behind Suspension and Arch bridges
Lesson Summary: What are the engineering and mathematical principles applied to the design and construction of suspension and arch bridges?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • have an understanding of the mathematical and engineering principles behind the construction of suspension and arch bridges
  • be knowledgeable about the process through which both suspension and arch bridges are designed and built. (Images of the progression if building these types of bridges would be good to use in meeting this objective.)
  • be introduced to some of the risks and potential errors that have or can been made in the construction of these type of bridges
  • understand the meaning of torsion, tension and compression and how these concepts impact the construction of suspension an arch bridges
  • have seen visual images of some of the great suspension or engineering bridges in the world
Short Description: What are the engineering and mathematical principles applied to the design and construction of suspension and arch bridges?

Lesson Title: Business Book  Discussion:  Marketing - "Buyology: Truth and Lies About Why We Buy": Martin Lindstrom
Lesson Summary: Lead a group of students in a discussion of the book/media and insights gained from it about business. Conducted via Teleconference or in person
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • recognize at least three key takeaways from the book/media they read
  • see how the book/media relates to the real world experience of the executive leading the discussion
  • be able to present a summary of their findings to fellow classmates


This would be a twenty to thirty minute time commitment either in person or by telephone
Short Description: Lead a group of students in a discussion of the book/media and insights gained from it about business. Conducted via Teleconference or in person

  • Define what a channel is

  • Describe advantages and disadvantages of using partner channels or owned channels
  • Provide examples of partner and owned channels

By the end of this lesson, students be able to:

  • Comprehend the criteria used to separate customer segments

Lesson Summary: When should I consider buying rather than renting a property and how to I go about finding, financing and closing the purchase of a property?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will

  • understand what a realtorÕs role is and what are the best methods to find and narrow down a list of properties that interest you
  • be aware of all of the expenses involved in purchasing a house including how mortgage financing works
  • be knowledgeable of the pros and cons of purchasing a house and have tools to enable you to make the Òbuy vs rentÓ decision
Short Description: When should I consider buying rather than renting a property and how to I go about finding, financing and closing the purchase of a property?

Lesson Title: Cancer Disease: overview of causes, types  and progression
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • understand what are the causes of cancer
  • know what are the different major types of cancer
  • be aware of the scale of cancer disease in the world today
Short Description: What are the causes of cancer and what are the major different types of cancer?

Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • understand what are the different ways cancer is treated
  • recognize how treatment of cancer has changed in the last century
  • be aware of recent and potential breakthrough treatments of cancer
Short Description: What are the ways cancer is treated, both now, in the past and potentially in the future.

Lesson Summary: Research an organization which serves many people in your city or local area (example: Metro Council Environmental Services (MCES) serves most people living in the metro area through its operation and maintenance of wastewater collection and treatment.) and determine what occupations they have that fit into the Career Fields of the Minnesota Career Information System (MCIS). What are the differing occupations within the organization? Where do they fit into the Career Fields of MCIS? What are the working conditions of those occupations within the organization? What are the wages of each? What are the requisite educational qualifications for the occupations? What is the Minnesota employment outlook for each?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
Through this lesson, students will:

  • become familiar with researching a local organization or business (what they do and how they serve others)
  • become familiar with how MCIS groups Career Fields and how these are broken down further into clusters and pathways.
  • understand how a local organizationsÕs occupations fit into the Career Fields.
  • learn specific information on various occupational requirements, wages, and Minnesota employment outlook.
  • choose an occupation within the organization which best fits his/her career profile (previously determined).
Short Description: Research an organization which serves many people in the Twin Cities seven-county metro area (example: Metro Council Environmental Services (MCES) serves most people living in the metro area through its operation and maintenance of wastewater collection and treatment.) and determine what occupations they have that fit into the Career Fields of the Minnesota Career Information System (MCIS). What are the differing occupations within the organization? Where do they fit into the Career Fields of MCIS? What are the working conditions of those occupations within the organization? What are the wages of each? What are the requisite educational qualifications for the occupations? What is the Minnesota employment outlook for each?

Lesson Summary: What are the differing types of jobs within a specific profession or industry? What is the day to day work like in that career? What are the growth prospect and salaries in that industry? What are the qualifications needed to work in that field?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, student will know:

  • the different types of careers in this industry
  • what are current growth prospects and wage levels in this industry
  • what the nature of the daily work is like for some of the different careers paths in this field
  • why the guest instructor enjoys working in this profession
  • what are the post secondary training pathways into this career field (direct to work, apprenticeship, 2 year or 4 year college options) and what are licensing/qualification requirement
Short Description: What are the differing types of jobs within a specific profession or industry? What is the day to day work like in that career? What are the growth prospect and salaries in that industry? What are the qualifications needed to work in that field?

Lesson Summary: Career Round Tables provide opportunities for our students to be introduced to STEAM career professionals with the intention of developing student Science Capital and building 21st Century Skills.
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
Lesson:

The career round table is a professional academic discussion between professionals and students with the goal of increasing an understanding of the utility and broad application of science qualifications, knowledge and skills used in science (e.g.that these can lead to a wide range of jobs). These professionals will represent a variety of professions from different STEAM fields to give students access to a variety of science professionals. Presenters will share experiences and information about their field to a small group of selected students who have potential interest in said field. Students will receive coaching from teachers on how to participate in an event of this nature and will prepare questions ahead of time to bring to the presentation. Following presentations, the lead teacher will conduct a reflection session to help students process and utilize information gained.

 

Lesson Activities:

Career Round Table Coaching

Timeline:

  • 1st session Ð introduction, provide template questions, research about company/profession
  • 2nd session Ð practice Òsmall talkÓ and people skills, develop more specific questions
  • 3rd session- Organizational Culture
  • What is Culture?
  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wd1bsxWeM6Q
  • 4rd session Ð Role play the interaction with the presenter
  • 5th session Ð Presentation by professional
  • 6th session Ð Reflection day

 

Science dimensions overview
Short Description: Career Round Tables provide opportunities for our students to be introduced to STEAM career professionals with the intention of developing student Science Capital and building 21st Century Skills.

Lesson Title: Chemical Elements: how their presence affects a substance
Lesson Summary: What impacts does the presence of different types of elements in a substance have upon that substance? How do we identify the presence of certain elements in a substance and how do we add or remove elements from a substance.
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:


  • understand how the presence, addition or removal of different elements impacts a substance such as water, soil, oil or any substance where the presence of certain elements can enhance or damage a substanceÕs properties (ie flouride or iron or calcium in water)
  • have seen examples of techniques to identify the presence of differing elements in a substance
  • know some techniques used to add or remove an element from a substance


This lesson would be valuable to teach as a culminating lesson to a class which had been introduced to the Periodic Table and the elements within it. The objective is for students to understand the impact different elements have upon our daily lives and the environment around us.


Soil & Agriculture

If you would like to approach this lesson from the perspective of elements in soil, the MN Dept. of Agriculture has great resources and a detailed lesson plan available here. The lesson was written by the Nutrients for Life Foundation.
Lesson Educational Standards:
Grade: 7

Strand:2. Physical Science

Substrand: 1. Matter 

Standard  ÒUnderstand that É1. The idea that matter is made up of atoms and molecules provides the basis for understanding the properties of matter. 

Code: 7.2.1.1.1

Benchmark: Recognize that all substances are composed of one or more of approximately one hundred elements and that the periodic table organizes the elements into groups with similar properties.
Short Description: What impacts does the presence of different types of elements in a substance have upon that substance? How do we identify the presence of certain elements in a substance and how do we add or remove elements from a substance.

Lesson Title: Child Development: Different Types of Development
Lesson Summary: This lesson would explore the physical, emotional and intellectual development in children and how to assess for different ages.
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will be able to answer the following questions:

  • Define physical, emotional and intellectual development.
  • Provide examples of each type of development at different age stages (infant, toddler, preschool, etc)
  • Describe different ways to assess development in children.
Short Description: This lesson would explore the physical, emotional and intellectual development in children and how to assess for different ages.

Lesson Summary: What does a Civil Engineer do? What is it like to be one?Lesson designed by David Kitzman, Minnetonka High School
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
In my Project Lead the Way (PLTW) Introduction to Engineering Design (IED) class, we spend several days exploring the various engineering career strands comparing what they do, the educational requirements, schools, certifications, skills needed, government vs. private employment etc. After my visit with Kimley-Horn, I decided it would be a good idea to bring in an actual Civil Engineer who would talk with my students and hopefully dispel some of the stereotypes young people sometimes develop.


Upon having a chance to meet with the Industry guest speaker, my students will be able to:

  • describe what a Civil Engineer does.
  • list what the educational requirements to become a Civil Engineer are.
  • list which schools they should be looking at for having the best opportunities in the field.
  • better understand what certifications they should obtain to be most successful in this field and list which ones fit their interests.
  • describe how they can obtain the certifications identified above and incorporate this into their career path.
  • explain the tradeoffs between choosing to work in the government vs. the private side.
  • most importantly say they met and talked with a Òreal liveÓ Civil Engineer and developed a more realistic version of who they are vs. what they maybe thought.
Lesson Educational Standards: ITEEA Standard 20: Construction Technologies: Infrastructure; Construction Processes and Procedures
Short Description: What does a Civil Engineer do? What is it like to be one?

Lesson Summary: What is civil engineering is and what kind of infrastructure projects do civil engineers work on?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • understand the type of work a civil engineer does and how it differs from the work done by a chemical, electrical and mechanical engineer
  • have seen examples of the type of projects and work done on them by civil engineers
  • understand the type of work a civil engineer does on a day to day basis and why this type of work is rewarding and fulfilling to a civil engineer
Short Description: How is civil engineering applied in the development of major transportation projects

Lesson Summary: How do engineers evaluate project sites and develop them for successful projects?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will: 

  • understand how civil engineers evaluate the suitability of different sites for construction
  • be aware of how differing types of sites can impact the cost of development and construction
  • have seen a variety real world construction site both pre and post development
Short Description: How do engineers evaluate project sites and develop them for successful projects?

Lesson Title: Client Projects for solar customer 1: Lab work
Lesson Summary: Teams of five students will assemble functional, small-scale solar energy systems in a laboratory setting.
Short Description: Teams of five students will assemble functional, small-scale solar energy systems in a laboratory setting.

Lesson Title: Client Projects for solar customer 2: Field work - Flat Roof
Lesson Summary: How do solar panel engineers conduct site assessments and preliminary feasibility for flat roof solar energy sites?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will have:

  • participated in and understand the methodology and process for assessing the feasibility and energy generation capacity for installing a solar panel on a flat roof
  • exercised math skills in the completion of this feasibility study. If trigonometry is used, that would be an added bonus for a learning outcome.


It would be preferable if the solar panel engineer who is guest instructing could provide, in advance of her/his visit, materials or case studies to enable students to complete calculations related to the feasibility study
Short Description: Student teams will conduct site assessments and preliminary feasibility for flat roof energy sites.

Lesson Title: Client Projects for solar customer 3: Field work - Sloped Roof
Lesson Summary: How do solar panel engineers conduct site assessments and preliminary feasibility for sloped roof solar energy sites?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will have:

  • participated in and understand the methodology and process for assessing the feasibility and energy generation capacity for installing a solar panel on a flat roof
  • exercised math skills in the completion of this feasibility study. If trigonometry is used, that would be an added bonus for a learning outcome.

 

It would be preferable if the solar panel engineer who is guest instructing could provide, in advance of her/his visit, materials or case studies to enable students to complete calculations related to the feasibility study
Short Description: Student teams will conduct site assessments and preliminary feasibility for sloped roof solar energy sites.

Lesson Title: Client Projects for solar customer 4: Field work - Ground mounted systems
Lesson Summary: How do solar engineers conduct site assessments and preliminary feasibility for ground mounted solar energy sites.
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will have:

  • participated in and understand the methodology and process for assessing the feasibility and energy generation capacity for installing a ground mounted solar system
  • exercised math skills in the completion of this feasibility study. If trigonometry is used, that wold be an added bonus for a learning outcome.


It would be preferable if the solar panel engineer who is guest instructing could provide, in advance of her/his visit, materials or case studies to enable students to complete calculations related to the feasibility study
Short Description: Student teams will conduct site assessments and preliminary feasibility for ground mounted solar energy sites.

Lesson Summary: What is climate change, what are its causes and the consequences of it and what actions can be taken to address it?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of the lesson, students will:


  • understand how levels of CO2 correlate to temperature changes
  • be aware of causes of climate change, both natural and man made
  • understand the consequences of rising temperatures on our weather, economy and society
  • know what the Paris agreement is and the commitments made by nations who are party to it
Short Description: What is climate change, what are its causes and the consequences of it and what actions can be taken to address it?

Lesson Summary: How can a reader use the practice of close reading to more fully understand a text?Why is close reading an important skill, and how can it be applied?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
Learning Objectives: Students will be able to:

  • Understand when and why to use close reading
  • Analyze an authorÕs point of view
  • Read for depth, rather than just skimming a text
  • Identify the details (word choice and meanings, facts, statistics, sentence structure, figurative language, allusions, etc.) of a text, and consider the connection between details and meaning.
  • Use the details of a text to draw conclusions about the main ideas and takeaways of a text
  • Support their main idea findings with details found from the close reading


 Resources:

  • On importance & application: Using a close reading practice in medicine Ð transferring this skill of noticing details and the whole to being a better doctor with a patient: https://www.narrativemedicine.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Chapter7_Principles_and_Practice_of_Narrative_Medicine.pdf & https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/03/education/edlife/03narrative.html


Tips:

  • Talk to the teacher about the type of text that would be best to practice on Ð a complex nonfiction piece? A research article? Different articles will have different focus points (e.g., in a research article, discuss the parts: abstract, introduction, discussion, conclusion, etc, and how to navigate each while reading closely).
Short Description: How is close reading applied in the professional world and why is it an essential skill in many professions?

Lesson Summary: What is the process for applying to college and how do I navigate that process?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • understand the process of applying to college
  • learn about differences in the process for students with disabilities
  • be aware of the emotional challenges of applying to college and the mechanisms to deal with such stress and anxiety
Short Description: What is the process for applying to college and how do I navigate that process?

Lesson Title: College or not: Post Secondary Career Opportunities
Lesson Summary: If a four year college pathway is not for me, what other career options are open to me?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • understand available options for a 2 year Associate degree or other vocational qualifications while working
  • recognize the pros and cons of entering the workforce straight away rather than go to college
  • hear from either former students or employers about the rewards and value of entering the workforce straight from school and how to build a long term career in a professional field without a four year college degree
Short Description: If a four year college pathway is not for me, what other career options are open to me?

Lesson Summary: What are the main principles to be applied in using different color combinations effectively?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson students will:

  • understand main color theories to apply with art and design
  • be able to define and give examples of primary, secondary, and tertiary/intermediate colors.
  • be introduced to color combinations such as analogous, complementary, monochromatic
  • be aware of Value scale, tones/tints/shades and other supporting color interactions that effect the intended message with color.


Potential incremental topics for color theory if time permits: monochromatic landscape, expressive self-portrait using warm or cool colored palettes, complementary color still life, or create three paintings using a triadic palette (student choice of landscape, figure painting or still life).
Lesson Educational Standards:
Visual Arts/Creating: #VA:Cr1.1

  • Anchor Standard: Generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.
  • Enduring Understanding: Creativity and innovative thinking are essential life skills that can be developed.
  • Essential Questions: What conditions, attitudes, and behaviors support creativity and innovative thinking? What factors prevent or encourage people to take creative risks? How does collaboration expand the creative process?


Grade Hs advanced: VA:Cr1.1.HSIII:

Visualize and hypothesize to generate plans for ideas and directions for creating art and design that can affect social change.


Visual Arts/Creating: #VA:Cr1.2

  • Anchor Standard: Generate and conceptualize artistic ideas and work.
  • Enduring Understanding: Artists and designers shape artistic investigations, following or breaking with traditions in pursuit of creative art making goals.
  • Essential Questions: How does knowing the contexts histories, & traditions of art forms help us create works of art & design? Why do artists follow or break from established traditions? How do artists determine what resources are needed to formulate artistic investigations.


Grade Hs advanced: VA:Cr1.2.HSIII:

_Choose from a range of materials and methods of traditional and contemporary artistic practices, following or breaking established conventions, to plan the making of multiple works of art and design based on a theme, idea, or concept.
Short Description: Practical guide to the color wheel, color harmony and and the creating visual effects using specific color combinations.

Lesson Summary: What is HIPAA, why is confidentiality so critically important in healthcare and what is the nature and importance of the patient / practitioner relationship in healthcare?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • recognize the importance of patient confidentiality in healthcare
  • know what HIPAA is and how it impacts the healthcare industry
  • have explored scenarios which allow the student to explore what is the correct and incorrect course of action in certain patient/practitioner situations. Specific situations where breaches of confidentiality might occur should be discussed as well as the appropriate way to communicate with various external parties in a health care situation.
  • recognize why patient/practitioner confidentiality is so important in the healthcare industry and understand the ramifications for breaches in that confidentiality 
  • be cognizant of the dangers of social media and its inappropriate use by healthcare practitioners
Short Description: For every health care practitioner, patient confidentiality is critical to managing patient / practitioner relationships successfully and operating effectively in their work.

Lesson Summary: Objective: For students to start being able to use soft skills to work with a customer on developing a plan for a construction project.
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
Project Directions: During this assignment student will develop a checklist for a sales call to a customer. The customer is considering adding a sunroom onto their house.

 

During this lesson students will useÉ


  • Industry professional will teach lesson on professionalism when interacting with customer at their home. Tips industry professional will cover.
  • Eye contact
  • Professional dress
  • Asking good questions
  • Educating customers about solutions
  • EtcÉ
  • Gather information to make a checklist of questions to be sure to talk with customers about.
  • Write a bid proposal for the designs the customer and contractor (student) come to a decision about.


Industry professionals will judge/grade bid proposals.


Materials supplied:


  • Sample bid forms
  • Sample contractor checklists
  • Time with industry professional
  • Ipad (students supplied)
Short Description: Objective: For students to start being able to use soft skills to work with a customer on developing a plan for a construction project.

Lesson Summary: How is the concept of correlation applied and used in specific professional fields and how do professionals approach the challenge of determine whether correlation does indicate causation or not?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • understand how correlation is used in making decisions in the professional world
  • have seen specific examples of how have calculated the correlation, r2 and other statistical measures to interpret a data set and determine the strength of the correlation
  • have seen examples of where correlation ­ causation and where correlation = causation


Bonus would be if students could be given a case study or a data set in advance of the class from the guest instructor to work on and present and compare their conclusions with those made by the guest instructor when they analyzed the data.
Lesson Educational Standards:
Common Core Standards

CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSS.ID.C.8

Compute (using technology) and interpret the correlation coefficient of a linear fit.


CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSS.ID.C.9

Distinguish between correlation and causation.


CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSS.ID.B.5

Summarize categorical data for two categories in two-way frequency tables. Interpret relative frequencies in the context of the data (including joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies). Recognize possible associations and trends in the data.


CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSS.ID.B.6

Represent data on two quantitative variables on a scatter plot, and describe how the variables are related.


MN Math Standards

9, 10, 11 Data Analysis & Probability Display and analyze data; use various measures associated with data to draw conclusions, identify trends and describe relationships. 9.4.1.3 Use scatterplots to analyze patterns and describe relationships between two variables. Using technology, determine regression lines (line of best fit) and correlation coefficients; use regression lines to make predictions and correlation coefficients to assess the reliability of those predictions.
Short Description: Application of correlation in the professional world

Lesson Summary: How are statistics used in data analytics across a variety of different industries and professional fields?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • have an overview of how data analytics are applied in the professional world
  • recognize the differing sub-fields within data analytics
  • have examined a specific case or cases that show the them the type of data problems they might be required to solve as a data analyst
  • have learnt about the impact data analytics is having on all professions today and how it is used to improve not only business performance but all aspects of our daily lives.
Lesson Educational Standards:
Common Core Standards

Summarize, represent, and interpret data on two categorical and quantitative variables

 

CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSS.ID.B.5

Summarize categorical data for two categories in two-way frequency tables. Interpret relative frequencies in the context of the data (including joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies). Recognize possible associations and trends in the data.

 

MN state Standards

9, 10, 11 Data Analysis & Probability Explain the uses of data and statistical thinking to draw inferences, make predictions and justify conclusions. 9.4.2.2 Identify and explain misleading uses of data; recognize when arguments based on data confuse correlation and causation. 9, 10, 11 Data Analysis & Probability Explain the uses of data and statistical thinking to draw inferences, make predictions and justify conclusions. 9.4.2.3 Design simple experiments and explain the impact of sampling methods, bias and the phrasing of questions asked during data collection.
Short Description: Introduction to data analytics in the professional world

Lesson Summary: This is a half day event for High School juniors and seniors with an interest in pursuing a college degree and a career in the rapidly growing field of data analytics. They will learn about what it is like to study data analytics in college and what internships and full time positions have been secured by students studying in this field
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this site visit, students will have:

  • completed a college level data analytics case study
  • experienced what it is like to participate in a college class with university professors and students
  • learned about careers within the field of data analytics
  • discovered what it is like to study data analytics at a college level


Site Visit Resources

Site Visit Examples

Lesson Summary: How can students design a digital brochure? Lesson Designed by Aimee Olson
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
Students will be able to:

  • use graphic design tools to create an aesthetically pleasing, easy to read, user friendly digital brochure that can be utilized online.
  • utilize photography and technical writing skills.
  • use info-graphics (brief & concise).
  • recognize the unique dietary needs of their audience.


Additional resources:

Use Adobe Spark for creation of brochure.

An enrichment activity could be to look at nutrition trends (gluten free- vegan or vegetarian) or life style options.
Short Description: How can students design a digital brochure?

Lesson Summary: How can start-ups and small businesses optimize their digital presence to build a successful online marketing campaign?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson:

  • students will understand the basics of building a successful online marketing campaign for all digital channels: search, video, social, email, and display.
  • understand best practices for developing and distributing video marketing content
  • identify what makes an email marketing campaign successful
Short Description: How can start-ups and small businesses optimize their digital presence to build a successful online marketing campaign?

Lesson Summary: What are the services and opportunities available to students with disabilities in college and how are these services different from the services I received in high school?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • understand the available services to students with disabilities in college
  • recognize the differences between the services available in college versus high school
  • hear from a either students or college counselors about what the college academic experience is like for students with disabilities
Short Description: What are the services and opportunities available to students with disabilities in college and how are these services different from the services I received in high school?

Lesson Title: Effective verbal communication in the workplace
Lesson Summary: How do I communicate in an appropriate and empathetic way with my work colleagues?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will have:

  • considered and learned about specific situations that require differing forms of verbal communication in the workplace
  • recognized when is the right and wrong time to communicate different types of verbal messages in the workplace
  • role played communicating different types of verbal information in the workplace
  • be able to understand non verbal communication within themselves and others
Short Description: How do I communicate in an appropriate and empathetic way with my work colleagues?

Lesson Summary: How do electric cars work, how does their performance and running cost compare to a gasoline fuel car and what does the future hold for electric cars?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • understand how an electric and hybrid car works
  • be able to compare the operating costs of owning an electric versus a gasolin car
  • understand the challenges facing the effort to have the US transition from a gasoline to an electric driven car fleet
Short Description: How do electric cars work, how does their performance and running cost compare to a gasoline fuel car and what does the future hold for electric cars?

Lesson Summary: How does the US power grid work, who owns it and how will changes in our energy sources change how the power grid works in the future?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • Understand how electricity is moved and made available across our nation
  • be aware of differing types of national power grid throughout the world
  • know who owns the national power grid and how it charges for its services
  • be aware of and be able to assess different plans for the future management of the national power grid
Short Description: How does the US power grid work, who owns it and how will changes in our energy sources change how the power grid works in the future?

Lesson Summary: How do we create electrical power systems that are safe to maintain and use?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of the lesson, students will:

  • understand the main principles of electrical safety
  • be aware of what voltage is 
  • know how fire safety hazards are eliminated in electrical work
  • understand what grounding and arc-fault protections are and what role they play in safe electrical power systems


How do we create electrical power systems that are safe to maintain and use?
Short Description: Principles of electrical safety, including voltage, grounding, arc-fault protections, fire safety hazards.

Lesson Summary: How are magnets used in light rail track? What kinds of sensors are used to make sure transportation is safe? What goes on behind the scenes at transportation operations maintenance facilities?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of this lesson, students will:

  • know how electro-magnetic power is used in transportation systems
  • seen examples of electro-magnetic systems work in a transportation system
Short Description: How are magnets used in light rail track? What kinds of sensors are used to make sure transportation is safe? What goes on behind the scenes at transportation operations maintenance facilities?

Lesson Summary: What role will electric power play in the future transportation system of the USA and how does this compare to other countries efforts to electrify their transportation systems?
Lesson Learning Outcomes:
By the end of the lesson, students will:

  • be aware of the role electric power will play in the future development of our transport needs
  • understand how electric power will impact both personal and mass transit
  • understand the challenges facing the adoption of electric power as the main component of our transportation system
  • Be aware of government policy and initiatives, both at the state and federal level, towards electrically powered transportation
Short Description: What role will electric power play in the future transportation system of the USA and how does this compare to other countries efforts to electrify their transportation systems?
